notes:
1. Standard Error of the Mean (SEM)

The Standard Error of the Mean quantifies how much the sample mean ($\bar{x}$) is expected to vary from the true population mean ($\mu$) if we were to take multiple samples. It is the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the mean.

$$ SE_{\bar{x}} = \frac{s}{\sqrt{n}} $$
  • $s$: Sample standard deviation.
  • $n$: Sample size.
  • As sample size ($n$) increases, the SEM decreases, meaning the sample mean becomes a more precise estimator of the population mean.

2. Standard Error of the Estimate ($S_{est}$ or $S_{yx}$)

In regression analysis, the Standard Error of the Estimate measures the accuracy of the regression model's predictions. It represents the average distance (residual) between the observed data points and the regression line.

$$ S_{yx} = \sqrt{\frac{\sum (y_i - \hat{y}_i)^2}{n - 2}} $$
  • $y_i$: Observed value.
  • $\hat{y}_i$: Predicted value from the regression equation.
  • $n-2$: Degrees of freedom for simple linear regression.

A lower $S_{yx}$ indicates a better fit of the model to the data.

solvedExamples.question: A sample of 100 items has a standard deviation of 20. What is the Standard Error of the Mean (SEM)?
solvedExamples.explanation: The formula for SEM is $SE = s / \sqrt{n}$. Here, $s=20$ and $n=100$. So, $SE = 20 / \sqrt{100} = 20 / 10 = 2.0$.

solvedExamples.question: How does quadrupling the sample size affect the Standard Error of the Mean?

options.text: It reduces it by a factor of 4.

solvedExamples.explanation: Since $SE \propto 1/\sqrt{n}$, if $n$ becomes $4n$, the new error is $1/\sqrt{4n} = 1/(2\sqrt{n}) = 0.5 \times$ the original error. Quadrupling the sample size cuts the uncertainty in half.
